p: NGI-1, a small-molecule OST inhibitor, was reported to directly target and block the function of the OST catalytic subunits STT3A and STT3B. Unlike tunicamycin, NGI-1 does not completely inhibit all the N-glycosylation sites, and this probably determines the reduced cellular toxicity of NGI-1, making it an excellent approach to modulate N-glycosylation in mammalian cells ( 61). To test the inhibitory effect of NGI-1 on the N-glycosylation of LASV GP, STT3A –, STT3B –, MAGT1 – TUSC3 –, and WT cells were infected with the rLCMV/LASV GPC virus and then treated with NGI-1 at the indicated concentrations. None of the concentrations showed cellular toxicity during the incubation time (data not shown). Cells were harvested at 36 hpi and subjected to Western blot analysis. As shown in Fig. 9A, NGI-1 was able to inhibit the glycosylation of LASV GP mediated by STT3A-OST (in STT3B – and MAGT1 – TUSC3 – cells) or STT3B-OST (in STT3A – cells) and impaired its proteolytic cleavage in a dose-dependent manner. At the same NGI-1 concentrations, hypoglycosylation of LASV GP was most severe in STT3B – and MAGT1 – TUSC3 – cells compared to that in STT3A – and WT cells.
